STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 17, 2025
Hope Mulder James
SAMARITAS - WEST
2080 UNION AVE SE STE A, Suite A
GRAND RAPIDS, MI, 49507-3247
Re: License #: CB410201266
Dear Hope Mulder James:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
September 9, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training
• (2) The foster parent training plan must provide for all the following:
• (b) Not less than 6 hours of training annually for each licensee after
the time periods specified in subdivisions (a) of this subrule.
One of eight foster home files reviewed did not have documentation the foster
parent completed 6 hours of annual training as required.
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training
• (4) At least 1 adult member of the household must have training in and
maintain a current certification in first aid and cardiopulmonary resuscitation
from the American Heart Association or the American Red Cross, or other
institution approved by the department.
One of eight foster home files reviewed did not have documentation that at least 1
adult household member maintained current CPR/First Aid certification.
CPA Rule 400.12415 Unusual incident reporting policy
• (1) An agency must adhere to the following incident reporting protocols:
2

• (a) Immediately notify the child's parents; the department licensing
authority; the lawyer guardian ad litem and court, as applicable; the
department; and the foster child's parents, if any of the following
occurs:
• (ii) The foster child is absent without legal permission.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation an incident
report was completed for a youth absent without legal permission.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/3/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/27/2024
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the following information
before the placement or replacement of a child:
• (a) Child's name.
• (b) Child’s date of birth.
• (c) Available known information about the child’s health.
• (d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
• (e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to the care
of the child.
• (f) All known behaviors of the child.
• (g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of the
child.
• (h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent to provide
a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster child and the
foster family, including information about siblings who do not reside in
the foster home as provided in federal law.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided the information in subsections (a-h) of this rule prior to placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/3/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/27/2024
10/3/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 10/31/2023
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child and parent
or parents, as follows:
3

• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at least once
every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of six independent living files reviewed did not have a service plan completed
timely as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/3/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/27/2024
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents and the foster
parents in the development of service plans to enable the parent or parents
and foster parents to understand the plan for the child and the parents' and
the foster parent's role in assisting the agency in carrying out the plan. An
agency shall give a copy to and review the parent-agency treatment plan with
the parent or parents and foster parents. The agency must inform the parent
or parents and foster parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the child and the child's family
is confidential.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the parent
agency treatment plan was provided and reviewed with parent.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Review incident reporting requirements.
• Be sure documents are uploaded timely.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
4

The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency renewal inspection was completed on 9/3/24 and the CAP was approved
on 9/27/24. The agency was cited for 13 violations, 2 of which were repeated this
year. Of those 2, there was an improvement in individual incidents of non-
compliance within 1 violation area and a slight increase in number of individual
incidents in the other area. In 2023, 11 violations were established, 2 of which
were repeated this year. All of the repeated violations remain close to the same
number of individual incidents of non-compliances. The agency will need to
establish additional corrective planning for the repeated violations to ensure a
reduction of incidents.
Special investigation 2025SIC0000237 was completed on 3/20/25 and the CAP
was approved on 4/22/25. The agency was found in non-compliance as an
independent living staff member did not confiscate a youth's vape when told about
it. The agency's CAP included terminating the staff person and providing ongoing
training regarding searches related to prohibited items as well as client
boundaries. The agency has complied with the CAP however similar concerns
were reported a few months later that resulted in the special investigation below.
Special investigation 2025SIC0000767 was completed on 7/1/25 and the CAP
was approved on 7/30/25. The agency was found in non-compliance as it was
determined an independent living staff admitted reporting for work while
intoxicated and purchasing THC gummies for youth under the age of 21. The
agency's CAP included terminating the staff person and providing ongoing training
regarding searches related to prohibited items as well as client boundaries. The
agency has complied with the CAP, and no further concerns have been noted.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. The chief administrator
indicated the agency as a whole experienced significant restructuring and turnover
with multiple manager and staff positions within the last year. The high number of
new staff have made it difficult at times to develop consistency with documentation
and timeframe practices. The chief administrator reported the agency has
continued to work through the steps outlined in their CAP and will continue to see
progress in several areas.
Financial Overview
There were no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisors and coworkers are available to assist as
needed. Staff did not report any concerns.
5

Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. All files were stored securely and
there is a cross shredder for CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
___________________________________9/17/2025____________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 17, 2025
